docs.snippet: Taking Questions: The author Catherine Blyth is answering selected readers' questions about her book, "The Art of Conversation."...
docs.lead_paragraph: Following is the third and final set of responses from Catherine Blyth, who answered selected readers' questions about her book, "The Art of Conversation." The book explores this neglected pleasure, from greetings to small talk to gossip to humor, including shop talk, love talk, compliments, difficult conversation and even shutting people up.
docs.abstract: Taking Questions: The author Catherine Blyth is answering selected readers' questions about her book, "The Art of Conversation."

headline.main: Answers About the Art of Conversation in N.Y., Part 3

docs.snippet: he Bagger says thanks again for the invite to the hoedown, which starts at 2 a.m. Swedish time. But right now he is scheduled to glimpse the Oscars from a press room deep in the recesses of the Kodak Theater, while fetching sodas for the guys who ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Other Oscar bloggers are more experienced (like Tom O'Neil), more beloved (Sasha Stone) or more schooled in cinema (Kris Tapley), but none of them gets invited every year to an Oscar party in Sweden. Each year, Christina Jeurling makes sure that the Bagger receives a lovely handcrafted invite. In the year "Departed" won, there was a lovely take on Martin Scorsese as a kind of puppet/action figure, last year's was a mobile that used some strike-themed art, and this year's design is an electoral motif with amazing little custom buttons for each best picture nominee.
docs.abstract: he Bagger says thanks again for the invite to the hoedown, which starts at 2 a.m. Swedish time. But right now he is scheduled to glimpse the Oscars from a press room deep in the recesses of the Kodak Theater, while fetching sodas for the guys who are going to do the actual work.

headline.main: A Swedish Invitation for a Meatball

docs.snippet: In a year when the Super Bowl played to excellent audiences, the Grammys did better than expected, the Emmys bounced back and movie attendance is holding up, who is to say that the show of shows might not have a little bounce in the ratings?...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger put on his curmudgeon suit yesterday and sprayed some bad attitude about this year's Oscars. But in a year when the Super Bowl scored excellent numbers, the Grammys did better than expected, and movie attendance is up significantly, who is to say that the show of shows might not have a little bounce in the ratings? At a time when there is bad news on every horizon, gathering around the tube for a little Oscar song and dance might sound just right.
docs.abstract: In a year when the Super Bowl played to excellent audiences, the Grammys did better than expected, the Emmys bounced back and movie attendance is holding up, who is to say that the show of shows might not have a little bounce in the ratings?

docs.snippet: Dave Karger is going with a "Slumdog Millionaire" sweep of seven awards, including picture, director, adapted screenplay, cinematography, editing, song and score. He's picking Kate Winslet and Sean Penn for lead actors, and Penelope Cruz and Heath...
docs.lead_paragraph: There are few Oscar savants more stalwart or respected than Dave Karger of Entertainment Weekly, and he is a particular favorite this time of year because his weekly deadlines compel him to do his picking ahead of time. Mr. Karger is going with a "Slumdog Millionaire" sweep of seven awards, including picture, director, adapted screenplay, cinematography, editing, song and score. He's picking Kate Winslet and Sean Penn for lead actors, and Penelope Cruz and Heath Ledger in the supporting category. The Bagger, who doesn't have to lock his picks until next Thursday, is in basic agreement, although he is leaning toward Mickey Rourke in actor and Viola Davis in the supporting female category. This is actually starting to get fun.
docs.abstract: Dave Karger is going with a "Slumdog Millionaire" sweep of seven awards, including picture, director, adapted screenplay, cinematography, editing, song and score. He's picking Kate Winslet and Sean Penn for lead actors, and Penelope Cruz and Heath Ledger in the supporting category.

He argues that the Academy's taste for what he calls miniature movies (ones that could just as easily ended up on HBO) is that these moviegoers are not exactly moviegoers:

docs.snippet: Peter Gabriel said that he would not perform his Oscar-nominated song “Down to Earth” on the Academy Awards show when he learned that he would not be performing the track in its entirety....
docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision that could shave an entire minute off the running time of the Academy Awards broadcast, Peter Gabriel said that he would not perform his Oscar-nominated song, “Down to Earth,” on the show, Variety reported. Mr. Gabriel, who is nominated with Thomas Newman for the song from the animated feature “Wall-E,” withdrew when he learned that he would not be performing the track in its entirety but only a portion of about 60 to 65 seconds in a medley of best-song contenders. In a video on his Web site, petergabriel.com, Mr. Gabriel said the situation was “unfortunate,” adding, “It’s not going to do me any harm to make a little protest, but I think for some of the other artists it’s not so easy.” He said he hoped the Soweto Gospel Choir, which is featured on the song, might perform in his place.
docs.abstract: Peter Gabriel said that he would not perform his Oscar-nominated song “Down to Earth” on the Academy Awards show when he learned that he would not be performing the track in its entirety.

headline.main: Peter Gabriel Won’t Perform at Oscars
